# Step 3 - ESNext

Right now, our javascript code follows [ES5 specifications](https://www.w3schools.com/js/js_es5.asp).

ES5 was released in 2009, and nobody codes with this version anymore. In this step, we upgrade the code to use ES6+.

Step 3.xxx focuses on JS only. No changes are made to HTML or CSS files.

## Step 3.1 - [ES6 classes](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Classes)

topics: **classes**

If you look at `game.component.js`, you can read the following.

```javascript
// front-end/src/app/game/game.component.js

for (var i in this._config.ids) {
  this._cards[i] = new CardComponent(this._config.ids[i]);
} //               ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
```

Did you know, your current codebase in fact uses Object Oriented Programming (_sort of_)? Altough legacy ES5 can call `new` to instanciate objects, it does not however have the `class` keyword.

As a workaround, ES5 achieves a "**class**" substitute with the help of `prorotypes`:

```js
/* class GameComponent constructor */
function GameComponent() {
  // ...
}

/* method GameComponent.init */
GameComponent.prototype.init = init;
```

> ![tip] Think of **`XXX.protoype`** as a place to put anything (typically, any field and function), that will be a member of the `XXX` class. A `new XXX()` then inherits from everything placed in the prototype.

With that in mind, you understand that both `GameComponent`, `WelcomeComponent`, `CardComponent` & `ScoreComponent` are all classes already, with a somewhat awkward syntax.

In this step, we rewrite `WelcomeComponent`, `GameComponent`, `CardComponent` & `ScoreComponent` `prototype`, and replace them by the `class` keyword with the new `class` keywork introduced with **ES6**

**Your job**

- open `card.component.js`
- Replace `function CardComponent() {...}` with `class CardComponent {...}`:

  ```javascript
  (function () {
    // card.component.js // before
    function CardComponent(id) {
      this._flipped = false;
      // constructor body
      // ...
    }
    // CardComponent methods
    CardComponent.prototype.getElement = getElement;
    // ...
  })();
  ```

  ```javascript
  // card.component.js // after
  (function () {
    class CardComponent {
      constructor(id) {
        this._flipped = false;
        // constructor body
        // ...
      }
    }
    // CardComponent methods
    getElement() {
        // ...
    }
    // ...
  })();
  ```

  > ![tip] Notice that some attributes are prefixed with a underscore. (`this._****`).
  > This convention is used to identify properties considered as private.

- create the methods: Whenever you see `CardComponent.prototype.XXX = ...`, turn the function into a method called `XXX() {}`:

  ```javascript
  class CardComponent {
    constructor(id) {
      // [1]
      // ...
    }

    getElement() {
      return this._elt;
    }

    flip() {
      this._imageElt.classList.toggle("flip");
      this._flipped = !this._flipped;
    }

    equals(card) {
      return card._id === this._id;
    }
  }
  ```

- create the `get`/`set` methods for `flipped` property:
  Whenever you see `Object.defineProperties(CLASS_NAME.prototype, { PROPERTY_NAME: { get: ..., set: ... } })`, move the function bodies in a couple of getter/setter

  ```js
  get flipped() {
      return this._flipped;
  }
  ```

- Leave as is all the stuff that does not belong to `CardComponent.prototype`.

- Test your application. Does the game still run? Great. Now, refactor all other components to ES6 classes as well.

> ![warning] As a java developer, it might look like Java classes and Javascript classes behave the same.
> This is not true. Do not forget: ES6 `class` is just syntactic sugar over `prototype`, and might produce some edge-cases.

> ![question] Can you think of at least 2 things that are possible with Java classes, but cannot be done with ES6 classes?

#### Checklist

- [ ] I know how to define ES6 classes
- [ ] I know what get/set properties are
- [ ] I left no unresolved `// TODO Step 3.1` on my code
- [ ] I tested the application, and it runs as usual

The code seems much more clean and concise with classes, isn't it? Let's continue our refactor in the next step.
